questions.question_text: What is true about Message-Driven Beans (MDBs)?

choices.C: Each MDBs can process messages only from a single client.
choices.D: MDBs retain data caches between client calls.

discussion.content: As per your provided line reference, answer A and B are also true.

Answer B.
Nonblocking I/O
1- Put the request in asynchronous mode
2- Obtain an in/output stream from request/response objects.
3- Assign a read/write listener to the stream.
4- Process the request/response inside the listener's callback methods

choices.C: Create a Callable class and delegate this operation to a ManagedExecutorService by using the dispatch method of AsyncContext.
choices.B: Define a ReadListener and assign it to the request input stream.
choices.A: Use a Runnable instance with the start () method of AsyncContext.
choices.D: Define an AsyncListener and assign it to the AsyncContext object.

discussion.content:
Answer A, D.

questions.question_text:
A Java EE application that uses an EJB container must communicate with a legacy system developed using non-Java technologies.
Which two Java EE technologies can be used in the integration tier of the application? (Choose two.)
Which statement is true about the relationship between HTTP and WebSockets?

discussion.content:
Answer B.
Traditional HTTP communication model assumes that each call is always originated by the client. Once a WebSocket connection is establish by HTTP handshake does not use HTTP after that.

choices.D: A WebSocket connection uses HTTP protocol to exchange data with the browser.
choices.B: A WebSocket connection is initialized with an HTTP handshake.
choices.A: A WebSocket connection is a bi-directional HTTP session with message-handling support.
choices.C: A WebSocket connection can be initialized by either client or server.

discussion.content:
Answer D
>0 - (value, TimeUnit)
0 - not wait
-1 - wait forever
